entry.value: This page features form focused controls in Rapid.

Continuing from the last page, we will cover some more useful, but simple, controls in Rapid. This page will be more catered towards controls you may find in a form, such as radio buttons and input boxes. These have, of course, been showcased on other pages in this Rapid demo application, however they have not been explicitly documented and gone into detail.

To begin this page we will be going into detail on input boxes. Inputs are a control that all forms, and most applications, can make use of. As seen throughout this demo application, input boxes can be used in many different ways in conjunction with the different actions and controls in Rapid. On a core level they allow users to enter data manually into a box. Rapid provides different types of input boxes, ranging from numbers, emails, read-only, and text areas.
I am a standard input box
I can hold a lot of text and can change size

Using the same concepts of style, the date control acts as a selector for users to specify a date. As you would expect from a date, the format can be changed to suit different regions, have a maximum and minimum date set from the current day, and have an age range restriction. It is also possible for manual entry of a date to be disabled, in the event only a certain specified format should be entered.

The next form control we are going to cover is the dropdown list. Like other form controls, you will likely find that you have encountered these somewhere else before so their concept will not be something completely alien. The dropdown control in Rapid is capable of providing many options, as many as you wish to specify, has support for keys, and has the capability to set an initial value to be selected.

Continuing with our form theme, we will now go over radio buttons and checkboxes. These are both fairly similar controls in concept, with a few differences in both the front-end and back-end. Like with the dropdown, these controls should not be a totally alien concept. Checkboxes have the capability of being turned on and off, however radio buttons must have a value, once one has been selected initially. Checkboes can be either true or false, and radio buttons can be any value, or code, specified in the Rapid designer. Radio buttons can be separated into individual groups, allowing separate radio button controls to link together.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"

// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"

// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"

For a more traditional version of the date control, the calendar control can be used. For the calendar control one of three date formats can be set, whether today's date is selected or not, a control that allows people to jump in yearly increments, and an option to manually select a date as the starting point.

The final form based control we are going to cover is the score control. Like other controls in Rapid, the score control can have it's options changed, codes used on those options, and can have an initial value. When setting the options it is important to note that this control works best when small values are used as options.

With a majority of the remaining form controls in Rapid covered we are now ready to move on to some of the more uncommon controls in Rapid. These controls may be lesser used, more specialist controls but they are still a vital part of Rapid and allow for more varied applications. As mentioned, it is possible to turn off controls if your app does not require their use in the Rapid Admin tool. Follow the links below to explore more of the controls available in Rapid.

[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C54_","text":"Input boxes are capable of having a placeholder, a value pre-set inside of them, to display when no
content is inside, a character limit to stop users entering long entries, and the ability to have their
type changed. For the phone and email types there will be no immediate difference on desktop devices,
however on a mobile or tablet device the keyboard that will display will be their respective layouts.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C119_","text":"When validation is used for the date control both date formats need to match in order for validation to pass. By
default, and to prevent wildly varying dates, Rapid has a year range of +10 years from today and -100 years from
today. By default, and for when the format is important, manual entry of data is disabled meaning users must
select a date using the datepicker user interface. This ensures the format stays as required.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C145_","text":"When it comes to data copying from a dropdown control in Rapid it is good to know what is being copied over.
Only having values in a dropdown will copy over these values, as shown with the first input box. Setting
both the values and codes will copy over the codes, unless specified. With codes enabled, copying over
values with no codes will have nothing copied over. In this same case, with validation used, if a value with
no code is selected then it will not pass validation in most cases.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C246_","text":"Our example showcases logic that can be used with radio buttons, their codes, and groups all in one. Whilst the
example has grouped radio buttons it is entirely possible to have radio buttons function in a yes/no question.
The same is also true for our checkboxes, in that they can be used to answer simple questions on your Rapid
application. Radio buttons can have their button position changed, can be set to horizontal or vertical, and
can have an initial value set. Checkboxes also have this initial value feature.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C357_","text":"When defining the selected date with the calendar control it is worth noting that whilst the date specified will be
selected, it will default to being on the current month. Clicking on a new date in the calendar will select that
date as the selected date instead.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C358_","text":"The score control is made up of a few different HTML components. Each component can be individually styled,
providing they are referenced correctly. For this score control we have changed the normal aesthetic,
provided by the Rapid theme, to that of a more colourful design. Likewise with everything else in Rapid,
and as mentioned before, every single control can be individually styled to create the look and feel that
best suits your app.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C54_","text":"Input boxes are capable of having a placeholder, a value pre-set inside of them, to display when no
content is inside, a character limit to stop users entering long entries, and the ability to have their
type changed. For the phone and email types there will be no immediate difference on desktop devices,
however on a mobile or tablet device the keyboard that will display will be their respective layouts.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C119_","text":"When validation is used for the date control both date formats need to match in order for validation to pass. By
default, and to prevent wildly varying dates, Rapid has a year range of +10 years from today and -100 years from
today. By default, and for when the format is important, manual entry of data is disabled meaning users must
select a date using the datepicker user interface. This ensures the format stays as required.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C145_","text":"When it comes to data copying from a dropdown control in Rapid it is good to know what is being copied over.
Only having values in a dropdown will copy over these values, as shown with the first input box. Setting
both the values and codes will copy over the codes, unless specified. With codes enabled, copying over
values with no codes will have nothing copied over. In this same case, with validation used, if a value with
no code is selected then it will not pass validation in most cases.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C246_","text":"Our example showcases logic that can be used with radio buttons, their codes, and groups all in one. Whilst the
example has grouped radio buttons it is entirely possible to have radio buttons function in a yes/no question.
The same is also true for our checkboxes, in that they can be used to answer simple questions on your Rapid
application. Radio buttons can have their button position changed, can be set to horizontal or vertical, and
can have an initial value set. Checkboxes also have this initial value feature.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C357_","text":"When defining the selected date with the calendar control it is worth noting that whilst the date specified will be
selected, it will default to being on the current month. Clicking on a new date in the calendar will select that
date as the selected date instead.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P20_C358_","text":"The score control is made up of a few different HTML components. Each component can be individually styled,
providing they are referenced correctly. For this score control we have changed the normal aesthetic,
provided by the Rapid theme, to that of a more colourful design. Likewise with everything else in Rapid,
and as mentioned before, every single control can be individually styled to create the look and feel that
best suits your app.","type":"hover"}]}

page.htmlBody:
This page features form focused controls in Rapid.

Continuing from the last page, we will cover some more useful, but simple, controls in Rapid. This page will be more catered towards controls you may find in a form, such as radio buttons and input boxes. These have, of course, been showcased on other pages in this Rapid demo application, however they have not been explicitly documented and gone into detail.To begin this page we will be going into detail on input boxes. Inputs are a control that all forms, and most applications, can make use of. As seen throughout this demo application, input boxes can be used in many different ways in conjunction with the different actions and controls in Rapid. On a core level they allow users to enter data manually into a box. Rapid provides different types of input boxes, ranging from numbers, emails, read-only, and text areas.
Using the same concepts of style, the date control acts as a selector for users to specify a date. As you would expect from a date, the format can be changed to suit different regions, have a maximum and minimum date set from the current day, and have an age range restriction. It is also possible for manual entry of a date to be disabled, in the event only a certain specified format should be entered.
The next form control we are going to cover is the dropdown list. Like other form controls, you will likely find that you have encountered these somewhere else before so their concept will not be something completely alien. The dropdown control in Rapid is capable of providing many options, as many as you wish to specify, has support for keys, and has the capability to set an initial value to be selected.
Continuing with our form theme, we will now go over radio buttons and checkboxes. These are both fairly similar controls in concept, with a few differences in both the front-end and back-end. Like with the dropdown, these controls should not be a totally alien concept. Checkboxes have the capability of being turned on and off, however radio buttons must have a value, once one has been selected initially. Checkboes can be either true or false, and radio buttons can be any value, or code, specified in the Rapid designer. Radio buttons can be separated into individual groups, allowing separate radio button controls to link together.
For a more traditional version of the date control, the calendar control can be used. For the calendar control one of three date formats can be set, whether today's date is selected or not, a control that allows people to jump in yearly increments, and an option to manually select a date as the starting point.

July 2016
SuMoTuWeThFrSa
12
3456789
10111213141516
17181920212223
24252627282930
31

July 2016
SuMoTuWeThFrSa
12
3456789
10111213141516
17181920212223
24252627282930
31
The final form based control we are going to cover is the score control. Like other controls in Rapid, the score control can have it's options changed, codes used on those options, and can have an initial value. When setting the options it is important to note that this control works best when small values are used as options.
How are you feeling today?123456789
With a majority of the remaining form controls in Rapid covered we are now ready to move on to some of the more uncommon controls in Rapid. These controls may be lesser used, more specialist controls but they are still a vital part of Rapid and allow for more varied applications. As mentioned, it is possible to turn off controls if your app does not require their use in the Rapid Admin tool. Follow the links below to explore more of the controls available in Rapid.Uncommon controls in RapidGraphical Rapid controls
page.name: 26_rapidControls2

rolesHtml.html:
This page features form focused controls in Rapid.

Continuing from the last page, we will cover some more useful, but simple, controls in Rapid. This page will be more catered towards controls you may find in a form, such as radio buttons and input boxes. These have, of course, been showcased on other pages in this Rapid demo application, however they have not been explicitly documented and gone into detail.To begin this page we will be going into detail on input boxes. Inputs are a control that all forms, and most applications, can make use of. As seen throughout this demo application, input boxes can be used in many different ways in conjunction with the different actions and controls in Rapid. On a core level they allow users to enter data manually into a box. Rapid provides different types of input boxes, ranging from numbers, emails, read-only, and text areas.
Using the same concepts of style, the date control acts as a selector for users to specify a date. As you would expect from a date, the format can be changed to suit different regions, have a maximum and minimum date set from the current day, and have an age range restriction. It is also possible for manual entry of a date to be disabled, in the event only a certain specified format should be entered.

Like other form controls, you will likely find that you have encountered these somewhere else before so their concept will not be something completely alien. Continuing with our form theme, we will now go over radio buttons and checkboxes. These are both fairly similar controls in concept, with a few differences in both the front-end and back-end. Like with the dropdown, these controls should not be a totally alien concept. Checkboxes have the capability of being turned on and off, however radio buttons must have a value, once one has been selected initially. Checkboes can be either true or false, and radio buttons can be any value, or code, specified in the Rapid designer. For a more traditional version of the date control, the calendar control can be used. page.title: Form controls
